page.text: SUBJECT: Broadstone at Littleton Station Rezoning from B-2 and R-3 to PD-R,
2100 W. Littleton Blvd. and 5759 S. Bemis Street
Should the city allow conversion of commercially zoned property to residential use at the intensity
proposed by the requested Planned Development zoning?
On June 24, 2013, the Planning Board reviewed the proposed rezoning and general planned
development plan for 250 units and voted 7-0 to deny Planning Board Resolution No. 13-03, which
recommended conditional approval. On July 8, 2013, the Board voted 7-0 to approve Planning Board
Resolution No. 13-04 that forwards a recommendation of denial to City Council.
The public hearing for City Council was set for July 30 at which time the applicant proposed the
• Reduced height from five stories to four;
• Reduced the number of units from 250 to 225 decreasing the density from 56 du/ac to 50 du/ac;
• Increased the building setback on Littleton Boulevard from 10 to 15 feet.
Instead of proceeding with the scheduled public hearing, City Council voted 6-1 to remand the rezoning
request back to the Planning Board for review in light of the changes to the project (minor, as defined in
10-12-4(D)2) proposed by the developer. In addition, the applicant is proposing berming on the west
side of the site. Constructing the berm in the city ditch easement will require a license from the City of
Englewood. Englewood city staff has expressed initial concern with this proposal.
The previous staff recommendation included twelve conditions, which were attached to the proposed
ordinance. The applicant has agreed to comply with all of the recommended conditions and has
incorporated them into the revised PD plan. The following table lists all the revisions included on the
attached PD Plan and references the corresponding sheet number of plan.

• The Citywide Goals, Sterne Park and Downtown Neighborhood Plan portions of the
• The Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study and Design Guidelines for the Sheriff’s Department Site

text.b: Following are the pertinent criteria from the above-referenced documents, which was used to
evaluate the proposal. The staff comments are denoted below each statement in italics

page.text: The proposal with the recommended conditions of approval is consistent with the following pertinent
Community-wide goals and policies of the COMPLAN:
Preserve Littleton’s unique identity by protecting historic structures and emphasizing
Littleton’s distinct social and economic heritage with consideration given to:
Encouragement of variety in housing stock and types of people.

text.i: June 24, 2013: With the walkout basement level, the west side of the building will be six stories for the
majority of the elevation. However, the two separate buildings break up the visual massing along with
additional step backs and design requirements will create at least five sub-masses. The proposed maximum
number of floors and setbacks from Littleton Blvd. (5’ step back above the 2
nd
floor, 25’ step back above the
rd
floor and then 70’ back above the 4
th
floor) lower the building massing significantly reinforcing the
prominence of the Historic Courthouse. Staff condition #4 is review of the architectural, site and landscape
design by the Planning Board thereby ensuring that the massing and architectural details will respect the
Historic Courthouse and result in an aesthetically pleasing view from downtown.

i.b: NOW: The lower building height, the greater setback from Littleton Boulevard, the screening of the
walkout basement level with a berm and the additional step backs and design requirements now give an
appearance of several three and four-story buildings along the western edge. The additional setback
from Littleton Boulevard combined with the lower building height further reduces the scale of the
northerly portion of the building in relation to the Historic Courthouse. Staff’s recommended condition
#4 as stated above has been added under the Development Conditions on Sheet 2.

page.text: Goal 2: Develop Littleton’s economic independence and reemphasize downtown as Littleton’s economic

text.i: : Development of the site at the full potential of the existing B-2 zoning will have greater
impact on the adjoining neighborhoods, which is in conflict with other goals to protect the
neighborhood. The additional residences will increase the market for Main Street and Littleton
Boulevard businesses and staff condition #5 provides the opportunity for a limited residential use. The
adopted design guidelines for this area recommend multiple family residential in this location to support
the nearby light rail transit station. Included in the attached application materials, the applicant has
provided a fiscal benefit comparison showing greater annual revenues and one-time fee and taxes for
the proposed residential development versus a mixed use allowed under the present B-2 zoning.

i.b: NOW: The above statement still applies. Recommended staff condition #5 is noted under the
Development Conditions on Sheet 2 of the PD Plan.

page.text: Goal 7: Promote and maintain an attractive and healthful living environment for present and future Littleton

text.i: June 24, 2013: The lower building heights and larger step-backs along Bemis and Littleton Boulevard
lessen the visual impact on the adjoining neighborhood. In addition, providing residential housing near the
light rail transit will encourage walking and another mode of travel reducing the use of motor vehicles. The
recommended conditions of approval include widening the sidewalk and street right-of-way for Bemis Street,
installing a traffic signal at Bemis and Littleton Blvd., widening the sidewalk on the Alamo Bridge to provide
safer pedestrian access to the transit and downtown, conveying an easement to construct a trail connecting
to the public trail system, and constructing a sustainable building. Refer to staff conditions #2, 7, 8, and 10.

i.b: NOW: The setbacks and stepbacks along Bemis have been increased from 20’ to 25’ for Floors 1 and 2,
and subsequently increased to 30’ for Floor 3 and 50’ for Floor 4. The setbacks and stepbacks along
Littleton Boulevard have been increased from 10’ to 15’ for Floors 1 and 2, from 15’ to 20’ for Floor 3,
from 35’ to 40’ for Floor 4. In addition, a fifth floor has been removed. The recommended staff
conditions 2, 7, 8 and 10, as described above have been incorporated into the revised PD Plan.

page.text: Housing Policy 11: Encourage known energy efficient construction techniques in all types of housing.

text.i: June 24, 2013: Condition #3 requires a LEED standard to be met.

i.b: NOW: This condition is noted under Development Conditions on Sheet 2 of the PD plan.

page.text: The City shall emphasize the use of the Planned Development (PD) technique for all
new development within the City and provide incentives for developers to use this technique.

text.i: June 24, 2013: Approval of a Planned Development Plan is included with the rezoning request to PD-R.
The PD process allows specific standards to be applied to a particular development in order to mitigate
impacts to the surrounding neighborhood and area. In addition to development standards noted on the
proposed PD Plan, Conditions 1 through 12 meet this policy.

i.b: NOW: The above statement still applies. Staff recommended conditions 1 through 12 have been noted
and incorporated in the revised PD plan.

page.text: New development in the interior of established neighborhoods, not adjacent to arterial
streets, should respect the existing densities and land uses of the neighborhoods in order that the character is

text.i: June 24, 2013: The proposal along with implementing the conditions of approval will result in a residential
development that is lower in scale and building mass, which is more compatible with the surrounding
neighborhood. Refer to conditions 1, 4, and 11.

i.b: NOW: Lowering the building height, removing the fifth floor, reducing the density, and increasing
setbacks have further reduced the scale and building mass making it more compatible with the
surrounding neighborhood. Staff recommended conditions 1, 4 and 11 are included in the revised
PD Plan.

page.text: Provide traffic controls on internal residential and collector streets to improve
safety and to maintain proper levels of traffic speed and volume.

text.i: June 24, 2013: The Littleton Boulevard Design Guidelines recommend properties on Littleton Boulevard
utilize the intersecting secondary streets, like Bemis Street, for access. The applicant proposes a traffic
signal at the intersection of Bemis and Littleton, and a “No Right Turn” sign on their site to prevent vehicles
exiting the development from traveling south into the neighborhood on Bemis Street. The applicant is
agreeable to placing other measures in the lease agreement (condition #6).

i.b: NOW: The applicant’s commitment to bearing the costs of the traffic signal and recommended condition
#6 are both noted on Sheet 2 of the revised PD Plan.

page.text: Transportation Policy 10: Maintain and improve existing sidewalks and bike systems so that safe
access is provided within the City.

text.i: Conditions 8 and 10 require widening of Bemis Street along the site’s frontage and
expanding the width of the sidewalk along the bridge over the railroad depression at Alamo to
accommodate increased pedestrian use.

i.b: NOW: Conditions 8 and 10 are included in the revised PD Plan both graphically and noted on Sheet

page.text: Policy LU-10: Development adjacent to the identified iconic structures should respect and not detract
from their prominence. (Staff note: The plan identifies the Courthouse as such a structure)
LU-10a: Require that the height, scale, building placement, and other design elements of new
construction, expansion, or other property changes respect and do not overwhelm iconic structures.
Employ techniques such as building setbacks and step-backs for upper stories, and further detail that
direction in the Downtown Design Standards and Guidelines.
Policy LU-12: Development in areas that are outside of downtown but immediately adjacent to
downtown gateways should be planned with consideration of their proximity to downtown and their
potential role and impact on downtown. The four gateways are located at Main Street/Littleton
Boulevard, Main Street/Alamo Street/Santa Fe Drive, Prince Street/Santa Fe Drive, and the Downtown
LU-12a: Plan new developments immediately adjacent to downtown gateways so that they improve
connections to downtown, function as part of a gateway to downtown, follow the same design standards,
and are consistent with the Downtown Neighborhood Plan.

text.i: Instead of one large building, the PD Plan proposes two separate buildings thereby
visually reducing the mass and scale of the project. The standards on the PD Plan and the
recommended conditions of approval provide building step-backs, which further reduce the scale of the
building in relation to the Historic Courthouse. Staff is also recommending a more robust architectural
review process because of the significance of the site (condition #4).

i.b: NOW: All graphics and notes on the PD Plan have been updated to show the new building design
with more traditional architecture consistent with the courthouse design. The new design is one level
shorter and steps farther back from Littleton Boulevard, which further reduces the scale of the
building in relation to the Historic Courthouse. Condition #4 is noted under the Development
Conditions on Sheet 2.

page.text: Neighborhood Goal 1: Preserve the unique character of the neighborhood and general “quality of life”
aspects, especially the mix of architectural styles, mature trees, and quiet atmosphere of the residential

text.i: June 24, 2013: The proposal along with implementing the conditions of approval will result in a residential
development that is lower in scale and building much more compatible with the surrounding neighborhood.
Implementing additional measures to reduce southbound traffic into the neighborhood is detailed in the
recommended conditions of approval. Staff is also recommending increasing the setback of the building on
Bemis Street (condition #1).

i.b: NOW: Lowering the building height, removing the fifth floor, reducing the density, and increasing
setbacks have further reduced the scale and building mass making it more compatible with the
surrounding neighborhood. The PD Plan now reflects the recommended increased building setback
on Bemis Street. The measures to reduce southbound traffic into the neighborhood are noted on
Sheet 2 of the revised PD Plan.

page.text: Neighborhood Goal 2: Improve transportation facilities and traffic controls only to the extent
necessary to improve safety and to provide good traffic circulation within the neighborhood.
Transportation Policy 1: That traffic controls in internal residential and collector streets be maintained
or improved to improve safety and to prevent further increases in speed and volume of traffic.

text.i: : The developer has committed to installing a traffic signal at Bemis and Littleton Blvd.
(condition #7).
Implementing additional measures to reduce southbound traffic into the neighborhood is
described in condition #6.

i.b: NOW: The developer’s commitment to both the traffic signal and measures to reduce southbound
traffic on Bemis (conditions 6 and 7) are noted on Sheet 2 of the revised PD Plan. The reduction in
the number of units will result in a reduction in the number vehicle trips generated.

page.text: That emphasis in the decision-making process be placed on the preservation of the
neighborhood as a sound, desirable residential area.

text.i: June 24, 2013: The design guidelines of the Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study recommend residential
development at a density of 50 units per acre. The proposal along with implementing the conditions of
approval will result in a residential development that is lower in scale and building mass, and is more
compatible with the surrounding neighborhood. Constructing two smaller building masses instead of one
large building mass; providing additional step-backs for floors above the second and third stories, design
requirements, which further visually break up the massing and lower the building near the courthouse meets
the intent of the Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study (condition #11). Emphasis in the decision-making
process to preserve the neighborhood will be accomplished with the recommended condition #4.

i.b: NOW: The revised proposal reduces the density to 50 du/ac. The conditions of approval, including
the referenced conditions #4 and #11 are incorporated into the revised PD Plan. The reduction in
building height, removal of the fifth floor and increased setbacks and stepbacks has further reduced
the scale and mass of the building making it more compatible with the surrounding neighborhood.

text.b: Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study Design Guidelines for Sheriff’s Site and Community

page.text: • 1C1.2 Building form next to Littleton Blvd. and Bemis Street should be a maximum of three
stories, stepping up in height away from the street.

text.i: : The setbacks along both Littleton Blvd. and Bemis Street are consistent with the above
guideline. The 1
st
and 2
nd
floors will be 10 feet from Littleton Blvd., 3rd floor will be 15 feet, and the 4th
floor will be 35 feet. The PD Plan proposes a 20 feet setback from Bemis for the 1
st
and 2
nd
floors, 25
feet for the 3
rd
floor and 45 feet for the 4
th
floor. Staff recommends that the 20 feet setback be increased
to 25 feet adding five feet more to the two upper setbacks to make this frontage more compatible with
the east side of Bemis (condition #1).

i.b: NOW: The setbacks and stepbacks along both Littleton Blvd. and Bemis Street have been increased.
The Bemis Street setback has been increased to 25’ for Floors 1 and 2, 30’ for Floor 3, and 50’ for
Floor 4. Littleton Blvd. setbacks are now 15’ for Floors 1-2, 20’ for Floor 3 and 40’ for Floor 4. The
fifth floor has been removed.

page.text: Goal 1: The architectural character should complement the existing historic architecture of this subarea.
Goal 2: To create buildings that provides human scale, interest, and variation.
• 1C3.1 All buildings should be designed especially for the context and character of the area.
• 1C3.2 The buildings should possess an architectural character that reinforces the historic
character of the existing buildings in this area.

text.i: : The greater setbacks and reduced building heights along Littleton Blvd. and Bemis
Street bring this building to a human scale with interest and variation. The larger step-backs above the
second story along Bemis Street make the building mass more compatible with the lower scale buildings
along Bemis Street and reinforce the prominence of the Courthouse. Refer to new conditions 1, 4, and

i.b: NOW: As described previously, the proposed changes will result in a development consistent with the
stated goals. Staff recommended conditions 1, 4, and 11 are incorporated in the revised PD Plan.

page.text: • 1C6.1 Sloped roofs are preferred over flat roofs.

text.i: While the primary roof form will be flat, the development guidelines on the PD Plan state that some
sloping roof forms may be used to create visual interest and to relate to the adjacent buildings.

page.text: • 2A1 Building Relationships Goal: To present an attractive west façade to the light rail station

text.i: : With the walkout basement level, the west side of the building will be six stories for the
majority of the elevation. However, the two separate buildings break up the visual massing along with
additional step backs and design requirements to create at least five-sub masses. Recommended
condition #11 will further modify the setback standards for both the west and south elevations so 33% of
the Level 5 of the southern building shall step back 25 feet from the setback of the Level 1. In addition,
recommended condition #4 employs a process, which will include affected residents and the Planning
Board during the finalization of the architectural design.

i.b: NOW:
The lower building height, the greater setback from Littleton Boulevard, the screening of the
walkout basement level with a berm and the additional step backs and design requirements now give an
appearance of several three and four-story buildings along the western edge as shown on Sheet 3 of the
PD plan. The additional setback from Littleton Boulevard combined with the lower building height
further reduces the scale of the northerly portion of the building in relation to the Historic Courthouse.
Staff’s recommended conditions #4 and #11 as stated above have been added to the revised PD Plan.

page.text: Goals: To reflect the scale and height of the adjacent neighborhood and historic courthouse.
To maintain a two to three story edge to Littleton Blvd, particularly along the south side to
provide more sun exposure to the street.
• 2C1.1: Higher building forms should be located at the southwest and west portions of the site
stepping down toward Littleton Boulevard and Bemis Street. No building shall exceed the height
of the courthouse, 81 feet. (Staff note: The cupola is 81 feet while the larger mass of the building

text.i: is shorter).

page.text: • 2C1.2: The building (s) along Bemis Street should respect the scale and pattern of the houses
across the street through such design strategies as the articulation of building form, column/pier
spacing, window pattern, and similar approaches.

text.i: : The plan proposes two separate structures similar to the above site plan. Additionally,
floor step backs above the second floor for the third and fourth stories along Bemis and Littleton Blvd.
respect the scale of the houses along Bemis and the prominence of the Courthouse. The taller portions
of the buildings will be concentrated at the southwest corner of the development.
As stated previously, recommended conditions of approval will further modify the setback standards for
both the west and south elevations and employ a process, which will include affected residents and the
Planning Board during the finalization of the architectural design (conditions 4 and 11).

i.b: NOW: As described previously, the proposed changes with greater setbacks and lower building
heights will result in a development consistent with the stated goals. Staff recommended conditions 4
and 11 are incorporated in the revised PD Plan.

text.i: June 24, 2013: The folded map included in the corridor study refers to medium density residential
development as up to 50 units per acre. The proposed density of 56 units per acre may be justified with the
recommended conditions, which include the developer providing trail connections, constructing a
sustainable building and providing safety improvements such as widening the Alamo bridge sidewalk and a
traffic signal at Bemis (conditions 2, 3, 7, and 10).

i.b: NOW: The proposed density has been reduced to 50 units per acre. Staff recommended conditions 2, 3, 7
and 10 are now incorporated in the revised PD Plan.

page.text: Section 10-2-23 (E) (4) (a) states that Planning Board shall base its recommendation on the conformance
of the proposed plan with the stated intent of the Planned Development District. Following are the
10-2-23 (A): Intent: The Planned Development (PD) District is hereby created to promote the public
health, safety, and general welfare by allowing more flexible development, based upon a
Application and Intent: Further, in the application of this Section it is the intent of the
1. Encourage more creative and effective use of land and public or private services, and to
accommodate changes in land development technology so that the resulting economies benefit
• The additional residences at this location will increase the market for Main Street and

text.i: Littleton Boulevard businesses and note #3 under Development Conditions on Sheet 2 of
the revised PD Plan provides the opportunity for a limited residential use.

page.text: 2. Encourage innovation and efficiency in residential development to meet the growing demands
for housing of all types and designs for persons of any social or economic status.
• With a 4% apartment vacancy rate in Littleton, the development will meet the demand for

text.i: apartment housing and provide new product to an existing older housing stock. New
energy efficient building materials and appliances will help conserve natural resources.

page.text: 3. Encourage innovative development or redevelopment of all land uses to meet the contemporary
needs of the community by providing for a greater variety and mix of uses including those which
may coexist on the same parcel or within the same building as shown on an approved general PD
• As stated above, the development will provide new housing near downtown Littleton and

text.i: the light rail.

page.text: 4. Provide a process, which relates the design and development of a site to the particular
• The planned development plan process allows specific standards to be applied to a

text.i: particular development in order to mitigate impacts to the surrounding neighborhood
and provide additional offsite improvements to benefit the community. The recommended
conditions of approval agreed to by the applicant have been incorporated into the revised
PD plan. This will assure that the project will meet the intent of this statement. The
project has been evaluated against and is found to meet the Littleton Boulevard Corridor
Study Design Guidelines for the Sheriff’s site, which were created and adopted by
Council to address the design and development of the subject site.

page.text: 5. Require that the nature and intensity of development be supported by adequate utilities,
transportation network, drainage systems, and open space to serve the development, and to
minimize impacts on adjacent existing and future development.
• The development will link to a trail network, is adjacent to transit, and provides on-site

text.i: recreation facilities designed for the expected population. Existing utilities and
roadways will serve the site. In addition, further safety improvements will be provided
such as a traffic signal at Bemis Street and widening the sidewalk on the Alamo bridge.

page.text: 6. Encourage development that is consistent with the policies and guidelines established in the
adopted Comprehensive Plan for the area and for the City.
• As previously described, the proposed density, the larger step-backs above the second

text.i: and third stories and constructing two smaller building masses instead of one large
structure, along with the recommended conditions, are consistent with the intent of the
COMPLAN and the Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study.

page.text: Staff finds that the proposed changes to the project are consistent with the COMPLAN and meets the
design guidelines of the Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study.
Per section 10-12-4(B)2(b), the Planning Board shall determine if the request meets the provisions of the
declaration of public policy as set forth in section 10-12-1. The Planning Board must therefore base its
recommendation on the consistency of the proposed rezoning with the pertinent goals and policies of the
COMPLAN. In addition, Planning Board must find that the proposed rezoning promotes the general
welfare of the community and it conforms with the stated intent of the planned development district as
Per Section 10-12-4(B) 2(b), the Board may vote to:
• Recommend approval of the proposed rezoning request: I move to approve Planning

text.b: Board Resolution No. 13-07 which forwards a recommendation of approval to City

page.text: • Recommend approval the request with conditions reasonably related to meeting the
criteria upon which the granting of the application would be based;
• Recommend approval of a higher classification than requested;
• Or table the matter, to a date certain, pending the provision of further information by the

text.b: A RESOLUTION OF THE PLANNING BOARD OF THE CITY
APPROVAL OF A REQUEST TO REZONE PROPERTY
KNOWN AS 2100 WEST LITTLETON BOULEVARD AND
5759 SOUTH BEMIS STREET, FROM B-2 COMMUNITY
BUSINESS AND R-3 SINGLE FAMILY RESIDENTIAL,

page.text: WHEREAS, the Planning Board of the City of Littleton, Colorado, held a public
hearing at its regular meeting of June 24, 2013 to consider a proposal to rezone from B-2 and R-3 to
PD-R property located at 2100 West Littleton Boulevard and 5759 South Bemis Street, respectively,
and more specifically described in Exhibit A, which is attached hereto and made a part hereof by this
WHEREAS, the Planning Board voted 7-0 to approve Planning Board Resolution 13-
04 that forwards a recommendation of denial to Council;
WHEREAS, prior to the City Council public hearing on July 30, 2013, the applicant
proposed changes to the application which City Council found significant in nature and voted 6-1 to
remand the modifications to the Planning Board for its review and recommendation;
WHEREAS, the Planning Board held a second public hearing at its regular meeting of
August 26, 2013 to consider the applicant’s modifications which includes a revised PD Plan
incorporating the twelve staff recommended conditions of approval in addition to: 1.) reducing the
building height from five stories to four, 2.) reducing the number of units from 250 to 225 thereby
decreasing the density from 56 du/ac to 50 du/ac, and 3.) increasing the building setback on Littleton
WHEREAS, the Planning Board considered evidence and testimony concerning the
proposed rezoning and revised general planned development plan at said public hearing.
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT RESOLVED BY THE PLANNING BOARD OF THE
The Planning Board finds that, with the modifications shown on the
revised PD Plan dated August 21, 2013, the proposal to rezone the property described on the attached
Exhibit A to multiple-family residential is consistent with the development guidelines of the
Littleton Boulevard Corridor Study and the goals and policies of the COMPLAN, conforms with the
stated intent of the planned development district as stated in Section 10-2-23 (A) and (B) of the
Littleton Municipal Code, and promotes the general welfare of the community:
The Planning Board does hereby forward a recommendation of
approval to the City Council on said proposed rezoning and general planned development plan as
INTRODUCED, READ AND ADOPTED at the regularly scheduled meeting of the Planning Board
of the City of Littleton, Colorado, held on the 26th day of August, 2013, at 7:00 p.m. in the Littleton
Center, 2255 West Berry Avenue, Littleton, Colorado, by the following vote:

A PARCEL OF LAND IN THE SOUTHWEST QUARTER OF THE SOUTHWEST
QUARTER OF SECTION 16, TOWNSHIP 5 SOUTH, RANGE 68 WEST OF THE 6TH
PRINCIPAL MERIDIAN, COUNTY OF ARAPAHOE, STATE OF COLORADO, MORE
